welcome.title: Welcome to MCParr
welcome.subtitle: Your AI gateway to control your homelab
welcome.description: MCParr centralizes control of all your homelab services through an AI-powered conversational interface.
welcome.guideInfo: This guide walks you through the initial setup. You can modify all these settings later.

import.success: Import successful! Moving to next step...

complete.title: Setup Complete!
complete.subtitle: MCParr is ready to use
complete.guideInfo: You can access this guide anytime from

services.title: Homelab Services
services.subtitle: Connect your applications
services.description: Configure the homelab services that MCParr will control. For each service, enter its URL, API key (or username and password depending on the service), and optionally an external URL for remote access. Test each service individually or all at once.
services.tip: In the Groups tab of the Services page, you can create service groups (e.g., Media with Plex, Tautulli, Overseerr) that will be used as tool endpoints for Open WebUI.
steps: Access the Services page via the navigation menu
Click "Add a service" and enter URL, API key or credentials
Configure the external URL if you want to access the service remotely
Test the connection (individually or all services)
Create service groups in the Groups tab to organize your endpoints

users.title: User Mapping
users.subtitle: Link your accounts across services
users.description: User mapping allows MCParr to know which account in Plex corresponds to the same user in Overseerr, Radarr, etc. This enables permission management and access to MCP tools.
users.tip: Auto detection works best with at least 2 configured services that have users.
steps: Access the Users page via the menu
Use the "Auto Detection" tab to scan your services
Validate suggestions or create manual mappings

groups.title: Groups & Permissions
groups.subtitle: Control access to MCP tools
groups.description: Groups define which MCP (Model Context Protocol) tools are accessible to your users. For example, an 'Admin' group might have access to all tools, while a 'User' group would only have access to read-only tools.
groups.tip: MCP tools allow AI to interact with your services. Permissions control what each group can do.
steps: Access the Groups page via the menu
Create groups (Admin, User, Family...) with "Create Group"
Assign MCP permissions to each group
Assign your users to the appropriate groups

mcp.title: MCP Server
mcp.subtitle: Model Context Protocol
mcp.description: The MCP server allows your AI to interact with your homelab services. View call history, test tools directly from the interface, configure tools in Open WebUI, and manage global search.
mcp.tip: Use the Config tab to configure tools directly in Open WebUI (if the service is properly configured) and to set up global search.
steps: View MCP call history in the History tab
Test tools directly from the Tools tab
Configure tools for Open WebUI in the Config tab
Set up Global Search to search across all your services

chains.title: Tool Chains
chains.subtitle: Automate your workflows
chains.description: Tool chains allow you to create automated action sequences. This lightens the logic the AI model needs to handle by defining responses and sequences based on specific configurations.
chains.tip: A well-configured chain allows the AI model to delegate complex workflows while maintaining precise control over the steps.
steps: Access the MCP page, Chains tab
Create a new chain with the desired tools
Define trigger conditions and parameters
Configure automatic responses and sequences

training.title: AI Training
training.subtitle: Customize your assistant
training.description: The training module allows you to train and customize your AI assistant based on your preferences and usage. Create custom prompts and fine-tune the AI's behavior.
training.tip: Custom prompts allow you to adapt the AI's behavior to your specific needs and interaction style.
steps: Review current system prompts
Create your own custom prompts for specific tasks
Test and refine AI responses
Manage history and training examples

monitoring.title: Monitoring
monitoring.subtitle: Monitor your system
monitoring.description: Monitoring allows you to track in real-time the status of your services, system performance, and AI interaction history. Quickly detect issues and optimize your infrastructure.
monitoring.tip: Proactive monitoring helps you identify and resolve issues before they impact your users.
steps: Check the real-time monitoring dashboard
Verify the health status of each service
Analyze performance metrics (CPU, RAM, network)
Configure alerts to be notified of issues

config.title: Configuration
config.subtitle: Customize MCParr
config.description: The configuration page centralizes all application settings: appearance, notifications, logs, dashboard, and backup. Customize MCParr to your preferences and export your configuration.
config.tip: Remember to regularly export your configuration so you can easily restore it if needed.
steps: Adjust the theme (light, dark, system)
Configure notifications and alerts
Set log level and auto-refresh
Export/import your configuration to back it up

help.title: Help System
help.subtitle: Built-in documentation
help.description: MCParr has a built-in help system accessible on each page via the help icon (?). The Help page centralizes all available site documentation for quick reference.
help.tip: Click the ? icon on each page to access contextual help for that section.
steps: Look for the help icon (?) on different pages
Click it to display contextual help
Access the Help page to see all documentation
Use search to quickly find information
